title: Do non-Filipinos know who Jose Rizal is? - Quora

response.answer_text: In Spanish schools he is studied broadly as a leader of the Philippines independence movement when we study late 19th century Spain, the Cuban Wars and the ’98 War (all clamped as “Spanish-American War” in the US). So most of uss have to learn about him in Spanish history class. On top of that we have these in Madrid and in some other Spanish cities: José Rizal's monument in Manila has a replica in Madrid  The ambassador of the Philippines and a local authority of Madrid commemorate him on the anniversary  There is a street with his name in Madrid  Or this plaque with a piece of a speech from him in Spanish  •“Dónde estáis jóvenes que habéis de encarnar en vosotros el vigor de la vida que ha huido de nuestras venas, la pureza de las ideas que se han manchado en nuestros cerebros y el fuego del entusiasmo que se ha apagado en nuestros corazones” • “Where are you youngsters who must incarnate in you the thrill of life that has fled our veins, the purity of the ideas that have been tempered in our brains and the fire of the enthusiasm that has faded out in our hearts” • This is a statue of him in Málaga in southern Spain for example  It's sort of ironic having so many statues in the country you want to break away from if you think about it.

From my experience of asking Americans born in the US mainland and who are based mostly in the East Coast, no one among them has heard of Jose Rizal, the Philippine national hero. But they generally get curious when I tell them something about Rizal. They generally think he's cool. I even tell them Rizal came to visit NYC one time. There's a marker on the building where he stayed then, as it was a hotel that time. It's by Madison Square Park in Manhattan. The last time I checked it, its ground floor is a Toys R Us store. What about you, if in case you're non Filipino, do you know who Jose Rizal is?

I do not know who is Jose Rizal until I visited the Philippines and visited the Rizal Park. I do think Jose Rizal with associate with Sun Yat Sen, who both wanted a regime change in their country, as a national hero of their country. I once told 2 Filipino maid while bringing them around Singapore about my opinion of Jose Rizal and Sun Yat Sen, they were very surprised about it. They told me that they never heard my opinion from other Singaporean who they frequently talked to or occasionally and was very happy to hear my comments on both of them (they both know who is Sun Yat Sen and the story behind him before I met them).

Anybody who is slightly intellectual and slightly into Nusantara and quite a bit more in Malaysia would know of the Filipino and Nusantaran warrior and nation-builder, Jose Rizal. The annual Rizal awards help keep his name in our minds. I have read some, not much, on him. He is captivating, alright. I would suspect the same but less so for Singaporeans. But then, we don't have that many intellectuals in Malaysia. Quora will change that.

Yes. The Philippines’ independence movement is included in Indonesian school history subject (at least when I was in senior high school). So, I do know him. Some Indonesians are named after him (for example: Jose Rizal Manua and Jose Rizal Jurnalis). We also have Jose Rizal Street in Medan, North Sumatra Province.
I know who Jose Rizal and I’m British. I also share a birthday with Rizal and read Noli me Tángere but I don’t remember much of it.
